root.text: by the way, noticed that a number of winning horses over the years seem to be owned by british aristocracy. is this meant to be a money piss away exercise or do horse owners end up making money on average too?

elements.text: by the way, noticed that a number of winning horses over the years seem to be owned by british aristocracy. is this meant to be a money piss away exercise or do horse owners end up making money on average too?

text: As far as I am aware, owning a horse is just the quickest way to lose your money. Anyone I know who has any financial involvement in horse ownership calls it an expensive hobby. You don't do it to make money

elements.text: As far as I am aware, owning a horse is just the quickest way to lose your money. Anyone I know who has any financial involvement in horse ownership calls it an expensive hobby. You don't do it to make money

text: Surely there's money to be made from betting though no?

elements.text: Surely there's money to be made from betting though no?

text: The post was about ownership, which is a sure fire way to lose money. That's why it tends to be the rich that do it (they can afford the loss)

elements.text: The post was about ownership, which is a sure fire way to lose money. That's why it tends to be the rich that do it (they can afford the loss)

text: The equivalent for the mega-rich is owning a football team :wink:

elements.text: The equivalent for the mega-rich is owning a football team

text: They are "vanity projects"

elements.text: They are "vanity projects"

text: morning, apologies if this is a basic question, im trying to get my head around how to improve my version control with SQL. I am wondering how people structure this with something like git. What does the workflow look like? How do you apply changes through environments. what should I track and what shouldnt I (i.e. everything including small data fixes?)

elements.text: morning, apologies if this is a basic question, im trying to get my head around how to improve my version control with SQL. I am wondering how people structure this with something like git. What does the workflow look like? How do you apply changes through environments. what should I track and what shouldnt I (i.e. everything including small data fixes?)

text: A problem I've never solved

elements.text: A problem I've never solved

text: I just have a file littered with pretty much every SQL query I've written

elements.text: I just have a file littered with pretty much every SQL query I've written

text: Am I right in thinking people create a seperate folder that is tracked, save updated files to that, push to github, then run that update in a sql editor

elements.text: Am I right in thinking people create a seperate folder that is tracked, save updated files to that, push to github, then run that update in a sql editor

text: conceptually I would like to be able to just track all the objects in my database over time and better test for regressions

elements.text: conceptually I would like to be able to just track all the objects in my database over time and better test for regressions

text: True SQL version control is very difficult

elements.text: True SQL version control is very difficult

text: If you want to do it properly you need to generate SQL DDL updates and store those

elements.text: If you want to do it properly you need to generate SQL DDL updates and store those

text: Also any data conversion queries as well

elements.text: Also any data conversion queries as well

text: As a solo developer I don't bother trying as the difficulties outweigh the benefits. I just take regular database backups so I can recover

elements.text: As a solo developer I don't bother trying as the difficulties outweigh the benefits. I just take regular database backups so I can recover

text: hmm yer seems like a nightmare, the thing I would like to be able to do (and maybe it exsists) is to be able to right click in SSMS / Azure data studio / SQL editor, alter proc make some changes commit and push then apply to the database

elements.text: hmm yer seems like a nightmare, the thing I would like to be able to do (and maybe it exsists) is to be able to right click in SSMS / Azure data studio / SQL editor, alter proc make some changes commit and push then apply to the database

text: Owning a horse means you have extra information which means you can make money betting on it

elements.text: Owning a horse means you have extra information which means you can make money betting on it

text: but the only way I can see this working maybe im missing something is to have a seperate tracked folder with all the scripts basically replicating the current database objects, apply changes to those files, then run into to sql server but that seems very messy to me and I can see it being very easy for the files to go out of sync with the database objects

elements.text: but the only way I can see this working maybe im missing something is to have a seperate tracked folder with all the scripts basically replicating the current database objects, apply changes to those files, then run into to sql server but that seems very messy to me and I can see it being very easy for the files to go out of sync with the database objects

text: You can - but to do this you really need some database design software that generated DDL update queries

elements.text: You can - but to do this you really need some database design software that generated DDL update queries

text: So the version control is part of the database design software, which automates the updates (generates the necessary SQL)

elements.text: So the version control is part of the database design software, which automates the updates (generates the necessary SQL)

text: But you need to design the database first, not update it manually

elements.text: But you need to design the database first, not update it manually

text:
<@ULDAVFDRP> are you using any tools for maintaining your schema such as flyway?
Generally you'd have a migration for every change and every change should be backwards compatible. i.e. no drop columns before all code that touches that column is live, just make them nullable

elements.text:
are you using any tools for maintaining your schema such as flyway?

attachments.title: Can Horse Owners Bet On Their Horse? | Betting Gods
attachments.text: Can horse owners bet on their horse is a question we often get asked and the answer is – yes ... Read PostCan Horse Owners Bet On Their Horse?

elements.text: Not so fast:

text: "What racehorse owners are not allowed to do is lay their own horses or bet on other people’s horses in races in which they have a runner"

text: So you get more back by winning that you do by betting on your nag

text: You will need a tool that at least can import your schema into the tool

elements.text: You will need a tool that at least can import your schema into the tool

text: I was a Rails developer for many years, and still run to it for DB migrations and schema.rb as a) I know it and b) it's the best solution I've worked with to date, but I'm sure it's a good inspiration for similar in other frameworks and tools. In terms of data version control - old fashioned snapshot/backups are the way to go (which you can also do with Rails using db:dump type commands).

elements.text: I was a Rails developer for many years, and still run to it for DB migrations and schema.rb as a) I know it and b) it's the best solution I've worked with to date, but I'm sure it's a good inspiration for similar in other frameworks and tools. In terms of data version control - old fashioned snapshot/backups are the way to go (which you can also do with Rails using db:dump type commands).

text: Does anyone know 100% what the criteria are for being able to view the Premium Charges tab off your Betfair account when logged into the website? I have seen a lot of contradictory nonsense spouted on twitter so am hoping to get a definitive answer to this on here.

elements.text: Does anyone know 100% what the criteria are for being able to view the Premium Charges tab off your Betfair account when logged into the website? I have seen a lot of contradictory nonsense spouted on twitter so am hoping to get a definitive answer to this on here.

text: I could see the PC tab when I started paying PC. Is that what you were asking?

elements.text: I could see the PC tab when I started paying PC. Is that what you were asking?

text: From the charges page `9.4.2 You'll only be considered for the Premium Charge if your account is in profit and only if the total charges generated since joining Betfair are less than 20%† of your gross profits.`

elements.text: From the charges page
9.4.2 You'll only be considered for the Premium Charge if your account is in profit and only if the total charges generated since joining Betfair are less than 20%† of your gross profits.

text: Yeah this is what I would have assumed to be the case but I have been hearing from people (no idea of their reliability) who can apparently acccess it if their account is in profit even though not yet paying premium charges.

elements.text: Yeah this is what I would have assumed to be the case but I have been hearing from people (no idea of their reliability) who can apparently acccess it if their account is in profit even though not yet paying premium charges.

text: Yeah I know that aspect <@UUCD6P13J> just want to confirm/deny the stuff I have heard that you get to view this even if you don't pay PC provided your account is lifetime in profit

elements.text: Yeah I know that aspect
just want to confirm/deny the stuff I have heard that you get to view this even if you don't pay PC provided your account is lifetime in profit

text: I'd guess you've generated quite a lot of charges so might get away with not paying it for a while

elements.text: I'd guess you've generated quite a lot of charges so might get away with not paying it for a while

My account it too old to be able to use the API to get a broad picture. I can only go back so far with it. Really just trying to estimate at what point I might start paying PC assuming things carry on being profitable in the short term future and lifetime commission seems to be the best variable I can use to guess when it could kick in. Calculation my commission now is a doddle but I have lost a lot of money over the years and have probably paid a lot of commission. Ill extract it from the excel files they sent me even though its a bit of faff.

text: :astonished:

In my manual betting days, I saw the tab once I had made quite a decent profit on my account. Playing a straight betting system, I would pay more than 40% commison, so I was nowhere near being eligible for the charge. Once I started losing, it disappeared. So I think it depends on profitability rather than actual eligibility for the charge.

text: What's the preferred way to look at all logs, generated by Flumine, for a particular market and strategy? I've found that my backtest result (using data that I recorded) for a market hasn't matched what actually happened, and I'm trying to find out why.
